situation: I’m just exploring and seeing if there are any interesting products around.
user_query: curate a list of products that i would be interested based on my profile from the web.

user_context.brand_preferences: This shopper is pragmatic about brands: they notice reputation and guarantees but do not exhibit blind brand loyalty. They treat a recognized name or warranty as a positive signal of reliability, yet will switch to lesser-known options if those offer equal or better value or functionality. Brand status matters when it signals consistent quality or better after-sales support, but it is not the sole deciding factor.
user_context.price_sensitivity: Price matters and is regularly weighed against perceived value. The user frequently calculates unit cost, calls out perceived overpricing, and will downgrade satisfaction when price does not match benefit. At the same time they will pay a premium for items that clearly deliver superior utility, durability, or enjoyment, so their sensitivity is conditional rather than absolute.
user_context.review_sensitivity: They rely on detailed, experience-driven information rather than headline scores alone. Ratings and reviews are used as practical probes: the user reads for real-world behavior, common failure modes, and setup or usability notes, and they incorporate other people's experiences into their own decision calculus. They both consult reviews before buying and contribute thorough reviews after using products, indicating an evidence-oriented approach to social proof.
user_context.functional_requirements: Decisions are driven first by whether a product performs the core job reliably and as advertised. The user expects clear, accurate claims and has low tolerance for misleading language or design choices that impede basic use. They accept trade-offs when the main function is strong (e.g., minor cosmetic or convenience issues) but will reject items with critical functional flaws; they also value warranties, documentation, and features that make usage and maintenance easier.
user_context.aesthetic_preferences: Visual appeal and finish matter but are secondary to usefulness. The shopper appreciates attractive, well-made design and will favor items that look and feel pleasant, but aesthetic choices are balanced against practicality — a nice look will not compensate for fit, durability, or annoyance in everyday use. They notice presentation and packaging, and design that enhances organization or handling earns extra credit.
user_context.purchase_preferences: They prefer transparent, reliable shopping experiences: clear descriptions, helpful documentation, responsive support, and reasonable return or replacement options. Fast delivery is appreciated but not emphasized; instead they prize seller reliability, accurate listings, and warranties that reduce perceived risk. Packaging and ease of installation matter insofar as they affect first-use experience, and the buyer values merchants who make post-purchase resolution straightforward.

brand_preferences: Product listing includes a manufacturer-backed warranty or documented after-sales support policy.
Brand or maker shows verifiable customer support channels (phone, email, or support portal) listed on the product page.
Brand history or reputation is cited in third-party sources or product documentation (e.g., press, certifications, awards) referenced on the listing.
price_sensitivity: Product price is accompanied by a clear feature/materials list that allows direct comparison of cost versus listed functionality.
Listing provides price-context information (e.g., comparable models or bundle components) enabling assessment of value-for-money.
Seller or manufacturer documents any additional ongoing costs (consumables, subscriptions, replacement parts) associated with ownership.
review_sensitivity: Listing contains multiple detailed user reviews that describe real-world setup, daily use, and longevity observations.
Reviews or Q&A include recurrent reports of specific failure modes or usability issues that can be tallied and compared.
At least some reviews include concrete measurements, usage conditions, or photographic evidence rather than only headline ratings.
functional_requirements: Product specification sheet lists clear, measurable parameters for the core function(s) (e.g., capacities, speeds, tolerances) relevant to advertised claims.
Manufacturer provides user documentation (manual, setup guide) and stated maintenance/repair instructions for routine upkeep.
Product listing or documentation specifies warranty coverage and conditions for functional defects or failures.
aesthetic_preferences: Product images include close-ups of finish, materials, and dimensions so visual quality and fit can be judged.
Packaging and presentation are documented or pictured to assess first-use experience and protection during shipping.
Design descriptions highlight organization or handling features (grips, compartments, cable routing) that improve practical use and storage.
purchase_preferences: Listing states a clear return, replacement, or refund policy and the timeframes/conditions for returns.
Seller listing includes explicit, verifiable delivery lead-time and shipping options and any associated costs.
Product page provides direct seller contact information and documented post-purchase support channels for issue resolution.

situation: I’m just exploring and seeing if there are any interesting products around.
user_query: curate a list of products that i would be interested based on my profile from the web.

user_context.brand_preferences: The user treats brand as a useful signal rather than an absolute rule. They tend to rely on recognizable or reliable names when they want assurance of quality, but they are comfortable trying lesser-known options when the perceived value or convenience is clear. Past positive experiences create loyalty, so a trustworthy brand that consistently meets expectations will earn repeat purchases. In short, brand helps narrow choices and reduce risk, but it is balanced against other practical factors rather than used as the sole deciding factor.
user_context.price_sensitivity: The user is price-aware but not strictly price-driven. They weigh cost against expected durability, convenience, and overall value: they will pay more for something that saves time, lasts longer, or solves a recurring problem, but they look for reasonable pricing and will favor sensible bargains or multipacks when they fit needs. They avoid paying a premium for features they don’t value, preferring a clear cost-to-benefit justification for higher-priced options.
user_context.review_sensitivity: Reviews and ratings are an important part of their decision process. They use social proof to validate how a product performs in everyday use, paying attention to both overall scores and detailed user comments about reliability, fit, or real-world performance. They value corroborated, practical feedback that highlights common trade-offs and are likely to trust patterns in reviews (recurring pros/cons) more than isolated extremes.
user_context.functional_requirements: The user takes a pragmatic, utility-first approach: a product must reliably perform its core tasks and make daily life easier. They expect adequate durability, good fit or sealing where relevant, and consistent performance without unnecessary complexity. They tolerate modest trade-offs in secondary areas (such as minor aesthetics or extra bells-and-whistles) when the primary function, convenience, or longevity is strong, but have low tolerance for failures that undermine basic usefulness.
user_context.aesthetic_preferences: Design matters, but in a restrained way. The user prefers clean, uncomplicated looks and evidence of solid construction over highly decorative or flashy styling. Visual appeal is viewed as a complement to function—attractive when it signals quality or fits into existing surroundings, but not a substitute for practical performance. Simple, well-made presentation earns preference; elaborate design is secondary.
user_context.purchase_preferences: They favor a smooth, low-effort shopping experience: clear product information, reliable fulfillment, protective packaging, and straightforward return or warranty support. Fast and predictable delivery and responsive customer service increase satisfaction, and they appreciate sellers who reduce friction (convenient formats, useful warranties, or consistent stock availability). Overall, they value predictability and low hassle in ordering, receiving, and, if necessary, resolving issues.

brand_preferences: Product listing displays a clear manufacturer/brand name recognizable in product metadata or packaging images
Manufacturer/brand page linked from the listing documents prior product lines or model history for the same category
Listing or brand page specifies manufacturer-backed support (warranty, customer service contact, or official parts/service) provided by the brand
price_sensitivity: Product price is accompanied by explicit value statements (e.g., claimed lifespan, time-saving features, or included multipack/consumables) that justify cost relative to alternatives
Listing presents comparable product options or configurations (e.g., single vs. multipack, base vs. upgraded) enabling assessment of cost-to-benefit trade-offs
Any premium price is accompanied by documented practical advantages (durability materials, extended warranty, or additional consumables) in the product description
review_sensitivity: Listing shows an aggregated rating score alongside the total count of user reviews
Product reviews include multiple independent user comments describing real-world reliability or consistent performance patterns
Reviews contain recurring, corroborated praise or complaints about core functions (durability, fit/seal, ease of use) rather than isolated one-off claims
functional_requirements: Product specification lists measurable core performance metrics relevant to use (e.g., capacity, runtime, load/weight limits, sealing rating) in the product details
Materials, construction, or durability claims are documented in the listing (e.g., stated materials, rated cycles, or tested standards) rather than implied by marketing language
Product description or spec sheet documents user-facing convenience features that reduce daily effort (e.g., quick-change components, simple maintenance instructions, or compatibility notes)
aesthetic_preferences: Product images show a clean, uncluttered design from multiple angles with emphasis on solid construction and neutral finishes
Listing describes materials or finishes in functional terms (e.g., matte metal, molded polymer) that signal restrained styling consistent with practical use
Color and form options, if provided, are presented as practical variants rather than decorative embellishments
purchase_preferences: Listing displays clear shipping estimates and fulfillment source (seller, marketplace, or manufacturer) to assess delivery predictability
Return policy and warranty terms are documented on the product page with clear timeframes and conditions
Seller profile or storefront includes indicators of reliability (seller rating, fulfillment history, or consistent stock availability) and accessible customer service contact information

situation: I’m just exploring and seeing if there are any interesting products around.
user_query: curate a list of products that i would be interested based on my profile from the web.

user_context.brand_preferences: The user treats brand as a useful signal but not a deciding law. They respect reputation and proven quality when it reduces uncertainty, yet are comfortable choosing lesser‑known options if the product delivers clear value or specific benefits. Brand loyalty arises when past purchases met expectations, but the user will trade brand prestige for better performance, value, or a specific feature.
user_context.price_sensitivity: The user is cost‑aware and weighs price against perceived value rather than pursuing the cheapest option automatically. They seek good bang‑for‑buck — willing to pay more for durability or a noticeably better experience, while expecting mid‑range purchases to offer clear performance or quality gains. Bargains and bulk purchases appeal when they align with practical needs, and price-related compromises are acceptable if explained by proportional benefits.
user_context.review_sensitivity: Reviews are an important part of the decision process; the user reads them critically and looks for concrete, experience‑based details rather than surface ratings. They value consensus and look for recurring pros and cons, sample‑size context, and practical tips that reveal real use‑case tradeoffs. Negative reports that explain how and why something failed carry more weight than generic low ratings, and demonstrated after‑sale experiences (returns, durability) influence trust.
user_context.functional_requirements: The user evaluates products primarily on clear, observable utility and how well they meet stated needs. They expect reliable performance, durability, and sensible trade‑offs; aesthetic or novelty features are secondary unless they affect usefulness. They prefer items that are easy to maintain and that provide predictable outcomes; small inconveniences are tolerable when offset by meaningful benefits, but recurring friction or unclear instructions lowers their tolerance quickly.
user_context.aesthetic_preferences: Visual appeal matters, but mostly in relation to perceived quality and longevity rather than trendiness. The user notices finish, fit and material quality and will downgrade an item if the presentation suggests poor manufacturing or shortcuts. Clean, thoughtful design that supports ease of use is preferred; purely decorative features are less influential unless they improve ergonomics or perceived value.
user_context.purchase_preferences: The user values a smooth, reliable shopping experience: clear product information, realistic photos and thorough descriptions, straightforward returns, and responsive customer service. Timely delivery and secure, neat packaging are expected, and warranties or guarantees increase purchase confidence. They appreciate sellers who provide practical guidance and transparent policies, and are more likely to repeat purchases from vendors who make post‑purchase support simple and reliable.

brand_preferences: Listing identifies the manufacturer or brand and links to a history or portfolio of past products or product lines on the seller site or official site
Product page documents brand-backed warranty, certification, or formal quality statement (e.g., manufacturer warranty terms) rather than only marketing claims
Third-party sources or press coverage referenced on the product page that demonstrate the brand's reputation or prior performance on similar products
price_sensitivity: Price is presented alongside a clear itemized list of included features, materials, or services so the premium (if any) can be directly compared to alternatives
Product page or seller listing shows at least one comparable model or configuration with a different price to allow value-for-money comparison
Seller displays return/refund or warranty coverage that justifies paying a higher price for durability or after‑sale support
review_sensitivity: Available reviews include multiple independent, experience-based comments that cite concrete use cases, durations, or performance metrics
Review set shows consistent recurring pros or cons across several reviews rather than isolated statements
At least one review or Q&A documents a failure mode or after‑sale experience (returns, repairs, longevity) with explanatory detail
functional_requirements: Product specifications list measurable performance or durability metrics (materials, expected lifespan, load/usage limits, or similar observable specs)
Instructions, maintenance requirements, or care guides are provided in writing and detail routine steps required to maintain predictable performance
Product description identifies core functional features and explicitly states any trade-offs or limitations that affect daily use
aesthetic_preferences: Product photos include close-up images of finish, seams, joints, or material texture to assess fit and manufacturing quality
Materials and finish are specified in the description (material type, coating, color options) rather than only showing stylized images
Design notes or images demonstrate that visual elements support ease of use (ergonomic shapes, intuitive controls, or unobstructed access points)
purchase_preferences: Product page provides clear, complete product information (specs, dimensions, weight) and realistic photos matching the description
Seller lists explicit return, refund, and warranty policies with timelines and conditions in plain text on the product page
Delivery estimates and shipping terms are displayed at checkout or on the product page, and packaging/fulfillment details are documented
Seller contact or customer service options are listed with response expectations (email, phone, chat) and available support hours

situation: I’m just exploring and seeing if there are any interesting products around.
user_query: curate a list of products that i would be interested based on my profile from the web.

user_context.brand_preferences: The user is pragmatically brand-aware rather than brand-loyal. They favor sellers or makers that demonstrate consistent quality and sensible design; a familiar name or reputation helps but is not the sole deciding factor. They are willing to try different brands when the expected value or practical benefits are clear, and they drop brands that fail to deliver promised results or reliability.
user_context.price_sensitivity: The user is moderately price-conscious: they will pay more for clear, tangible benefits but react negatively when price feels disconnected from quantity, durability, or usefulness. Cost influences decisions, especially when cheaper alternatives offer similar real-world value, yet they accept paying a premium for convenience, reliability, or a noticeably better experience.
user_context.review_sensitivity: The user treats ratings and reviews as a practical tool rather than gospel. They look for specific, repeatable signals in other buyers’ comments (missing parts, durability issues, ease of use) to set expectations, and they balance averages with the substance of individual reviews. They also contribute their own detailed feedback, indicating they both consume and produce social proof to refine future choices.
user_context.functional_requirements: The user evaluates products primarily on whether they reliably perform core promises and make everyday tasks easier. They emphasize ease of use, consistency, and basic durability, tolerating minor compromises in secondary areas only if the main function holds up. Missing items, failures to work as advertised, or products that introduce new hassles reduce satisfaction quickly.
user_context.aesthetic_preferences: The user appreciates good, unobtrusive design that communicates quality and improves usability. Visual appeal and presentation are welcomed when they complement function, but aesthetics are secondary to practical performance; a pleasing look is a plus so long as it does not undermine usefulness or value.
user_context.purchase_preferences: The user prefers straightforward, low-friction shopping experiences: accurate product descriptions, reliable fulfillment, clear return or remedy options, and responsive customer support. Fast delivery is desirable but correctness and seller reliability matter more. They value packaging and presentation when relevant (e.g., gifting), and they expect clear information about setup, ongoing costs, or trade-offs so they can make informed choices.

brand_preferences: Manufacturer or seller documentation describes ongoing product support, firmware updates, or service availability for this product line.
Product listing or manufacturer materials cite verifiable third-party certifications, professional endorsements, or industry recognition for this product or brand.
Public records or seller disclosures indicate prior product recalls, formal complaints, or discontinuations for related models, allowing assessment of reliability history.
price_sensitivity: Product price is accompanied by a clear itemized list of included components and accessories to evaluate unit value.
Listing or seller pages provide direct price comparisons to similar models or bundles from the same seller to assess relative value.
All additional costs (shipping, recommended accessories, setup fees, consumables, subscriptions) are disclosed in the product information.
review_sensitivity: A substantive number of buyer reviews include specific, repeatable observations about core performance (e.g., durability, missing parts, ease of use) that can be counted and compared.
Observable proportion of reviews include photos or videos demonstrating real-world use and outcomes.
Seller responses to negative reviews are present and describe corrective actions, refunds, replacements, or explanations for reported issues.
functional_requirements: Product specifications explicitly list the core functions and measurable performance metrics relevant to the item’s primary purpose.
Package contents and accessory lists in the product listing match the components required for initial operation without additional purchases.
Manufacturer or seller provides setup instructions and basic troubleshooting steps in the product documentation or listing.
aesthetic_preferences: Product imagery presents the design from multiple angles and close-ups showing materials and finish to evaluate unobtrusive, quality-focused styling.
Available color and material options are described alongside any usability impact (grip, visibility, cleaning) in the product information.
Packaging images or descriptions indicate presentational quality while also showing protective packaging to confirm aesthetics do not compromise function.
purchase_preferences: Return policy and warranty terms are stated with clear remedies, timeframes, and any conditions in the listing.
Fulfillment information includes expected delivery windows and tracking availability from the seller or platform.
Seller contact channels for support are listed and include documented response commitments or published average response times.
Listing discloses setup requirements and any anticipated ongoing costs (consumables, maintenance, subscriptions) relevant to ownership decisions.

situation: I’m just exploring and seeing if there are any interesting products around.
user_query: curate a list of products that i would be interested based on my profile from the web.

user_context.brand_preferences: This shopper approaches brands pragmatically rather than loyally. Brand reputation is a useful shortcut when it signals consistent quality or reliable fit, but they are comfortable trying different makers when value, suitability, or features align better with their needs. They will adopt familiar brands when past experience was positive, yet they’ll readily choose lesser-known or store-label options if those offer clearer practical benefits or lower ongoing costs.
user_context.price_sensitivity: The user displays moderate price sensitivity: cost matters, but it is weighed against usefulness, longevity, and total ownership cost. They favor purchases that deliver clear value or lower recurring expenses, and they tolerate higher upfront prices when they expect better performance or durability for family use. At the same time, they prefer economical choices for lower-stakes items or for children’s goods where affordability and replaceability matter more.
user_context.review_sensitivity: Reviews and ratings are an important input but not a determinative one. The user reads social proof to identify common strengths and recurring problems, then interprets that information through their own priorities (comfort, convenience, safety). They pay special attention to reviewer details about fit, feel, and real-world use, using consensus signals to filter options while still trusting personal testing for final judgment.
user_context.functional_requirements: This shopper evaluates products primarily by whether they reliably perform the intended task and reduce friction in daily life. Comfort, ease of use, and durability are prioritized; they have low tolerance for shortcomings that affect comfort or fundamental function. They accept trade-offs when they are explicit and justified (e.g., compactness for portability), but will reject items that fail on core expectations even if other features are attractive.
user_context.aesthetic_preferences: Design matters, but typically as a complement to function. The user appreciates clean, simple, and thoughtfully presented items and enjoys small whimsical or elegant touches when they don’t undermine usability. Visual appeal can sway decisions when multiple options perform similarly, yet tactile feel and fit often outweigh purely decorative features.
user_context.purchase_preferences: They favor a convenient, transparent shopping experience: clear product information and images, easy assembly or simple setup, and dependable seller support. Logistics such as manageable packaging, realistic size/weight expectations, and reasonable return options influence satisfaction. Warranties, included accessories, and straightforward care instructions increase confidence in a purchase, especially for household items and products used by children.

brand_preferences: Product listing or manufacturer page documents a track record of consistent quality or reliable fit for similar products (e.g., case studies, product line history, or third‑party brand profile available).
Alternative or lesser‑known makers provide explicit comparative benefits (e.g., lower ongoing costs, clearer feature set, or explicit suitability statements) in the product description or spec sheet.
Past purchase or ownership notes from the brand appear in reviews with specific, repeatable positive outcomes for comfort, durability, or fit.
price_sensitivity: Product price is presented alongside documented durability or longevity indicators (e.g., materials, expected lifespan, or warranty) so higher upfront cost can be assessed against expected longevity.
Listing discloses expected recurring or ownership costs (e.g., consumables, replacement parts, maintenance) or explicitly states low ongoing costs.
Cheaper or store‑label alternatives include explicit trade‑offs in specifications or features in the product description (e.g., thinner materials, fewer included accessories) to justify lower price.
review_sensitivity: User reviews include multiple first‑hand descriptions of fit, comfort, or real‑world use with specific examples that can be cross‑checked against product specs or images.
Review summaries or QA highlight recurring problems or strengths (e.g., same issue reported by several reviewers) so consensus signals are identifiable.
At least one credible review or test report evaluates durability or ease of use under realistic conditions described in the review text.
functional_requirements: Core functional specifications required for the product’s intended task are explicitly listed (e.g., dimensions, materials, weight, performance metrics) and match stated use cases.
Product description or manual documents ease‑of‑use features (e.g., setup steps, operating controls) and indicates required user effort or tools for setup.
Materials and construction details are provided and address durability expectations (e.g., material type, reinforcement, water/resistance ratings if applicable).
Accessories or components needed for core function are included or clearly listed as excluded in the product information.
aesthetic_preferences: Product images and descriptions show a clean, simple design language with limited decorative elements and clear visual presentation of form and finish.
Materials and surface finishes are described or shown close‑up so tactile feel and texture can be judged from images and text.
Optional small decorative or elegant touches are documented without compromising described usability (e.g., no hidden closures that impede function are shown or mentioned).
purchase_preferences: Product page provides clear, high‑quality images and comprehensive product information (spec sheet, dimensions, materials, included items) within the listing.
Assembly or setup instructions are included or downloadable from the seller/manufacturer page and indicate approximate required time or tools.
Seller return policy and warranty terms are stated on the product page and specify the process for returns, repairs, or replacements.
Packaging, shipping weight, or dimensional information is provided so logistics and realistic size/weight expectations can be verified.
